channel.title: BBC News - Middle East
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Pegasus spyware seller: Blame our customers, not us, for hacking
item.description: NSO Group tells BBC News: "The finger-pointing should be at the customer."

item.title: Pegasus: Princess Latifa and Princess Haya numbers 'among leaks'
item.description: Numbers used by Princesses Latifa and Haya are reportedly found in a database at the heart of the leaks.

item.title: The 12-year-old becoming Tokyo's youngest Olympian
item.description: Hend Zaza from Syria reveals her inspiration for getting into table tennis at such a young age.

item.title: Hackers reportedly demand $50m from Saudi Aramco over data leak
item.description: The world's most valuable oil producer confirmed to the BBC that company files had been leaked.

item.title: Israel PM warns Ben & Jerry's owner Unilever of consequences over sales ban
item.description: The ice cream maker's parent company Unilever is told "strong action" will be taken against boycotts.

item.title: Top Trump aide charged with illegal UAE lobbying
item.description: Thomas Barrack is alleged to have lobbied the US government on behalf of the United Arab Emirates.

item.title: Iraq attack: Bombing at Baghdad market kills Eid shoppers
item.description: At least 30 people are killed in an attack on a busy market in Iraq's capital, security sources say.

item.title: Esraa Abdel Fattah: Egyptian activist released from prison
item.description: Esraa Abdel Fattah earned the moniker "Facebook Girl" for her role in the 2011 revolution.

item.title: Oil producing nations agree deal to control prices
item.description: The Opec cartel and Russia will boost supply which should see petrol prices at the pumps come down.

item.title: In pictures: Masks and social distancing at downsized Hajj
item.description: Only about 60,000 pilgrims living in Saudi Arabia were eligible to take part this year.

item.title: Iran protests: One killed in water crisis demonstration
item.description: Iran is facing a severe drought, and there is growing public anger over water and power shortages.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Egypt's Sherif to 'play with heart' in historic medal bid
item.description: Mayar Sherif will play 'with her heart' as she becomes the first Egyptian woman to play Olympic tennis for her country.

item.title: Pegasus: Who are the alleged victims of spyware targeting?
item.description: Jamal Khashoggi's wife and the editor of the Financial Times are among those said to be targeted.

item.title: The referee making Olympic history
item.description: The first Arab and African woman to referee 3x3 basketball at the Olympics shares how her Muslim faith has guided her career.

item.title: Olympics: Defying threats, Iranian athletes speak out to back ban
item.description: Olympics organisers are being urged to investigate allegations of threats, discrimination and abuse.

item.title: Islamic State children in Syria face a lifetime in prison
item.description: A BBC investigation found that children, whose parents supported IS, are caught in a conveyor belt of incarceration.

item.title: 'My husband was an angel - then he raped me'
item.description: Marital rape has long been a taboo issue in Egypt, but now victims are beginning to speak out.

item.title: Khashoggi murder: US softens towards Saudi leader
item.description: Saudi Arabia's crown prince was shunned after the 2018 killing, but the kingdom is back in business.

item.title: Olympic Games: The daring escape sparked by one forbidden glance
item.description: At the Atlanta Olympics of 1996, Iraqi weightlifter Raed Ahmed took a huge gamble - inspired by one look from President Clinton.

item.title: Jehan Sadat: Egypt's first lady who transformed women's rights
item.description: Jehan Sadat, whose husband was assassinated in a televised event in 1981, has died at the age of 88.

item.title: River Nile dam: Why Ethiopia can't stop it being filled
item.description: The massive hydroelectric plant is not like a bath with a tap that can be turned on and off at will.

item.title: After Lod violence, Israeli city's residents fear for the future
item.description: Both Jewish and Arab Israelis feel unprotected after intercommunal violence in the Israeli city.

item.title: Nizar Banat: Palestinians turn on leaders after activist's death
item.description: Rare protests call for ousting of the president as anger builds over the man's death in custody.

item.title: The precarious life of a Gaza fisherman
item.description: Fishermen in Gaza eke out a precarious living amid restrictions over where they can cast their nets.

item.title: Female genital mutilation (FGM): 'I had it, but my daughters won't'
item.description: Two mothers subjected to FGM tell how they will not let their daughters suffer the same.

item.title: Covid-19 tests while you wait in Israeli airport
item.description: Ben Gurion airport in Israel has introduced fast Covid-19 tests for travellers.

item.title: Iraqi firefighters tackle blaze in Covid ward
item.description: More than 50 people have died after a fire broke out in a coronavirus isolation ward at a hospital in Iraq.

item.title: Videographer goes viral with sheep drone shots
item.description: Lior Patel's drone footage of sheep has been viewed more than 100,000 times on Facebook.

item.title: Lebanon’s ‘suffocating’ energy crisis
item.description: Six-year-old Sedra is one of the people whose lives have been put at risk by the country's energy crisis.

item.title: Cash-strapped Lebanese army sells helicopter rides
item.description: The army is trying to boost its finances, which have been hit by Lebanon's severe economic crisis.
